title: What are the features of a first generation computer? - Quora
tags: What Are the Branches of X?

response.answer_text: The first generation (1940–1956) used vacuum tubes. Examples are ENIAC, UNIVAC I, IBM 650, IBM 701 etc. According to this list, there were 104 different vacuum tube computers produced between 1942 and 1963. The early relay computers could also be included here (Z3, Harvard Mark 1). They filled large rooms. Punched cards and paper tape were used for input and output initially. 80-column punched cards had already become a standard decades earlier through the use of unit record equipment, primarily manufactured by IBM, which could do sorting, collating and tabulating before computers came along. Punched paper tape was already in use by teletype machines. Line printers, also used as output from mainframe computers, had been used earlier along with punched card equipment. IBM 026 keypunch, introduced in 1949:  Magnetic tape was first used to record computer data in 1951 on the UNIVAC I, and was quickly adopted by IBM as well. Magnetic tape was used as both an input medium (punched cards would be copied onto tape off-line, and then input to the computer much faster than using a card reader), and as a storage medium, much like USB drives today. Densities started at 200 six-bit characters per inch, equivalent to about 2 MB per 7-track 1200 inch long reel. This gradually increased, so by 1973 one could record 170 MB on a 9-track 2400 inch reel at 6250 characters per inch. UNIVAC I, with tape drives in the background:  First generation computers had clock speeds of several hundred kHz to a few MHz. The UNIVAC I had a 2.25 MHz clock. Initial first-generation computers had very little internal read-write memory. ENIAC had none, except for its 20 10-digit accumulators. Other early computers used combinations of electrostatic, mercury delay line, and drum memories. The Whirlwind (1951) was the first use of core memory - a whopping 128 bytes.The IBM 701 (1952) still used 72 Williams tubes, each of which stored 1024 bits (same as 128 bytes in today’s computers), for a total of 9 KB of memory. It rented for $12,000 a month! A later model, the IBM 704 (1954) had 18 KB of core memory. Although very early first-generation computers were programmed in machine language, and later many were still being programmed using assembler, high-level languages were also used. FORTRAN was first introduced on the IBM 709, Lisp first implemented on the IBM 704, and COBOL was available on the UNIVAC II, all first-generation machines.

Very large scale arrays of numerous interconnected vacuum tube devices and related electronics equipment ( and therefore, miles of cabling ) ; 3. Crude interface to humans - usually only punched paper tape ; 4. A veritable bevy of full time technicians, constantly checking said valve arrays for any burnt out vacuum tubes, and replacing them as soon as that array could be safely de-powered ; 5. ( Perhaps ) the original ‘bug’ - - being an amusing anecdote about a moth having once fallen into an electronic array, causing a short circuit ; 6. A Managing Director somewhere around, telling people that ‘five computers will be the most the world will ever need’ ( famous quote - true ? or, not ) ; 7. A large room to house all said equipment ; 8. A large power feed-in ; 9. Various researchers requesting time to run calculations on the machine ( they would rarely be ‘in’ the computer room, but would attend on the running of the program they had wanted written possibly in order to measure how long said result was produced ; MY experience was both as Undergraduate student early 1970′s, when Melb. Uni. operated a large central CDC computer ; and also, with the earlier FUJITSU Computer Company of Australia, programming in COBOL their ‘74’ machine ; & many later computers ( frankly, until by early 1990′s, I was a bit ‘over’ doing that ) ; Someone even older than me, may hold more accurate recollections as mine are 2nd hand, via my late father.
